title: Learning to Reason from Feedback at Test-Time
author: Yanyang Li (The Chinese University of Hong Kong), Michael R. Lyu (The Chinese University of Hong Kong), Liwei Wang (The Chinese University of Hong Kong), ...
relevance_why: The paper's focus on feedback utilization could enhance audio processing tasks where incremental adjustments based on prior attempts are beneficial, similar to improving audio generation or restoration processes.
background: An iterative process where a model generates attempts to solve a problem, receives feedback on each attempt, and uses this feedback to improve its subsequent attempts.
contribution: This paper introduces Feedback-based Test-Time Training (FTTT) and a learnable test-time optimizer (OPTUNE) to enhance reasoning capabilities of language models during inference, achieving improved performance across several tasks.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods either relied on long sequences of context to correct mistakes or independently generated answers without learning from past attempts.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work allows the model to adjust its weights based on feedback, enabling it to utilize past experiences without significant computational overhead.

key_innovation: Utilizes a test-time optimization framework that updates model weights based on real-time feedback, contrasting with earlier methods that primarily focused on in-context adjustments or independent outputs.
real_world_impact: This approach could lead to more effective applications of language models in real-time tasks such as interactive dialogue systems or responsive coding assistants, enhancing user experience and solution accuracy.
limitations: The approach currently relies on binary feedback, limiting the complexity of information that can be extracted from each interaction.

new_terms.Feedback-based Test-Time Training (FTTT): **Feedback-based Test-Time Training (FTTT)** is a method to optimize model performance during runtime using feedback from previous attempts to inform and improve future predictions.
